[Statement 1]: Both mowing and grazing are alternatives to prescribed burning for fen vegetation management.
[Statement 2]: Mowing and grazing have distinct effects on fen vegetation.
[Statement 3]: Mowing alters overall plant community composition compared to no mowing or grazing.
[Statement 4]: Mowing increased the cover of fen- or wet meadow-characteristic plants.
[Statement 5]: Mowing increased total moss or bryophyte cover.
[Statement 6]: Mowing reduced the cover or abundance of at least one group of herbs including bindweed, reeds, sedges, purple moor grass and grass-like plants overall.
[Statement 7]: Mowing increased plant species richness compared to no mowing or grazing.
[Statement 8]: Fens managed by mowing had greater species richness of butterflies than fens managed by cattle grazing.
[Statement 9]: Grazing creates a different plant community composition compared to mown fen meadows.
[Statement 10]: Grazing increased the cover of some herb groups including cottongrasses, sedges or all grass-like plants.
[Statement 11]: Grazing reduced purple moor grass cover.
[Statement 12]: Grazed fen meadows contained fewer fen-characteristic plant species than mown meadows.
[Statement 13]: Grazed fen meadows contained fewer total plant species than mown meadows.
[Statement 14]: Plant species richness increased after grazing was reinstated.
[Statement 15]: Grazing typically had no effect on plant species richness.
[Statement 16]: The abundance of bog/fen-characteristic plants was similar in grazed and ungrazed fen meadows.
[Statement 17]: Grazed fen meadows had a similar vegetation structure to mown meadows.
[Statement 18]: Recently cut fens had fewer large copper eggs than uncut fens.
[Statement 19]: Recently cut fens had lower caterpillar survival than uncut fens.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the effects of different interventions designed to manipulate water levels on drained peatlands without planting?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several water level manipulation interventions have been studied on drained peatlands without planting.
[Statement 2]: Rewetting peatlands by raising the water table was evaluated in 36 studies across bogs, fens, and other peatlands.
[Statement 3]: The intervention of rewetting peatlands typically caused drier grassland communities to be replaced by more wetland- or peatland-characteristic communities.
[Statement 4]: Rewetted plots developed different plant communities compared to drained plots.
[Statement 5]: Rewetting peatlands increased Sphagnum moss cover or abundance in 12 studies across multiple countries.
[Statement 6]: Three studies on rewetting peatlands reported mixed responses by Sphagnum species.
[Statement 7]: Two studies on rewetting peatlands found no effect on Sphagnum moss cover or abundance.
[Statement 8]: The rewetting intervention increased cover of various herb groups.
[Statement 9]: The cover of sedges increased in 13 of 15 studies on rewetting peatlands.
[Statement 10]: The cover of cottongrass increased in 8 of 9 studies on rewetting peatlands.
[Statement 11]: The cover of reeds and rushes increased in 5 of 7 studies on rewetting peatlands.
[Statement 12]: Purple moor grass cover was typically reduced by rewetting peatlands.
[Statement 13]: Tree and shrub cover was generally reduced or unaffected by rewetting peatlands.
[Statement 14]: The effects of rewetting peatlands on overall plant species richness were mixed.
[Statement 15]: Six studies on rewetting peatlands reported increases in plant species richness.
[Statement 16]: Five studies on rewetting peatlands found no effect on plant species richness.
[Statement 17]: One study on rewetting peatlands reported reduced plant species diversity.
[Statement 18]: Irrigation of peatlands without planting was studied in only two investigations.
[Statement 19]: In a Canadian bog, irrigation increased Sphagnum moss shoots after one growing season.
[Statement 20]: In a Canadian bog, irrigation had no effect on Sphagnum moss shoots after two seasons.
[Statement 21]: In a German fen, irrigation led to colonization by wetland- and fen-characteristic herbs.
[Statement 22]: In a German fen, the cover of dryland grasses decreased due to irrigation.
[Statement 23]: Draining or replacing acidic water was evaluated in two fen studies in the Netherlands.
[Statement 24]: Draining or replacing acidic water showed mixed effects on Sphagnum moss and herb cover after 4-5 years, depending on species and whether moss was also removed.
[Statement 25]: One study on draining or replacing acidic water reported increased plant species richness.
